Built with Web Components

Style and Functionality Encapsulation for Free

Why Web Components?

What, why, and (most importantly) how?

<!-- Sample PwrSlide presentation code -->
<pwr-deck>
  <pwr-slide>
    <ul>
      <li>No more <div> soup!</li>
      <li>JS functionality (e.g. animations, slide entrance/exit callbacks) baked into custom tags</li>
    </ul>
  </pwr-slide>
</pwr-deck>
  • Web Components allow for the creation of custom HTML tags with unique styles and functionality (imagine the ability to create complex tags like the <video> tag!)
    •
  • Using web components allows PwrSlide to embrace the declarative power of HTML, making your presentations easier to read and create
    •
  • Instead of ugly <div> soup, you get clean, declarative code
    •
  • Check out the Polymer Project for more information about this exciting new spec
    •

So What Does This Mean for You?

The Pros and Cons of Using Web Components and PwrSlides

Pros
  • It's declarative: no more confusing code that's impossible to read and maintain
    •
  • Style and function encapsulation make previously difficult or impossible tasks easy (imagine embedding a presentation inside a presentation - see slide 8)
    •
  • It's modular: another benefit of encapsulation, now you can start building presentations within existing apps without worrying about cross-contamination of JS
    •
  • Most importantly, it's Pwrful
    • Using Polymer and JS encapsulation allows for nearly limitless extensibility and customization by enabling custom callbacks, animations, and nesting that previously would have been incredibly difficult and/or convoluted
Cons
  • PwrSlide is built using the developing web components spec and the Polymer polyfill library, both of which are currently in development
    • Ergo, as with anything under active development, this project may have its fair share of bugs (I welcome your input to make PwrSlide better!)
    •
  • Because PwrSlide uses Shadow DOM, HTML Imports, and other developing specs, only the evergreen browsers are supported (and even then, I would recommend that you stay away from IE, for your own sake)
    •
  • Due to the fact that many features required by web components must be polyfilled, even in modern browsers, some of PwrSlide's features may detriment page load times
    •

PwrSlide Features!

And Now for Some Good Stuff

Tons of Animations!

Built with a Powerful Animation Framework

  • PwrSlide.html ships with over 50 animations from Animate.css
  • PwrSlides and PwrPieces descend from the PwrAnimated Object
    • Custom attributes give fine-grain control over each animated component of your presentation
      •
    • Animated components have access to several powerful animation methods
      •
  • Wrap any regular HTML element in <pwr-piece> tags for them to become animated
    • Tags are animated by the slide in descending order
      •
    • Add the 'show' attribute to the component to show its contents initially
      •

PwrAnimated

<pwr-animated entrance exit onentry onexit>
Attributes
  • entrance: specify the entrance animation name
  • exit: specify the exit animation name
  • onentry: optional callback executed after entrance animation
  • onexit: optional callback executed before exit animation
    • NOTE: callbacks are bound by default to the tag on which they are called

PwrAnimated

PwrAnimated = {
  animateIn: function() { ... },
  animateOut: function() { ... },
  applyAnimation: function(animationName) { ... },
  removeAnimations: function() { ... }
};
Methods
  • animateIn( ): queue the target component's entrance animation
  • animateOut( ): queue the target component's exit animation
  • applyAnimation(animationName): applies the given animationName to the component
  • removeAnimations( ): removes any animations from the component

Animation Callbacks

Every Transition, Do Something Cool

<!-- All kinds of callbacks! -->
<pwr-slide onentry="alert('Hi! I am an entrance callback on this slide');">
  <ul>
    <pwr-piece exit="fadeOut" onexit="alert('And I am an exit callback on this piece');">
      <li>Deep, meaningful presentation insight</li>
    </pwr-piece>
  </ul>
</pwr-slide>
  • Animation callbacks allow you to perform complex manipulations of your presentation as elements enter and leave the view
    •
  • Callbacks are handled similarly to the familiar "onclick" HTML attribute; just specify your code in quotes and let PwrSlide handle the rest
    •
  • Allow for the presentation of time-sensitive code, giving you real-time interactivity within your presentation
    •
  • For an example of animation callbacks, check out the color-changing function on the next slide
    •

Custom Color Themes

Add A Splash of Color to Your Presentations


<script type='text/javascript'>
  function helloWorld(world) {
    for (var i = 42; --i >= 0;) {
      alert('Hello ' + String(world));
    }
  }
</script>
  • PwrSlide also ships with six custom color themes to allow you to add some color to your slides
    • Currently supports "red", "blue", "green", "gold", "salmon", and "black" themes
  • Simply add the corresponsing color class to a given slide to apply the color theme
  • Color themes have all been written in Sass using declarative variables for attributes, allowing for easy customization
  • Also supports prettyPrint code blocks
